title: THE FAMILY BAKERY
style_prefix: Children's book illustration, warm painterly style with soft brush strokes. NO TEXT IN IMAGE.

character_refs.layla: Layla - girl with curly dark brown hair, yellow bow on top, teal hoodie with golden sun design
character_refs.riley: Riley - girl with straight dark hair, pink bow, purple dress with white stars
character_refs.ellis: Ellis - boy with blonde hair, blue eyes, orange and blue soccer jersey
character_refs.benny: Benny - friendly brown teddy bear character wearing green plaid scarf

scenes.script: Mr. Mason picked up a wooden stamp. It had a pretty pattern. 'This came from Italy,' he said. 'From a tiny village. A bakery had been there for one hundred years.'
scenes.prompt: Mr. Mason in attic holding up ornate wooden bread stamp with carved pattern. Friends leaning in to see. Warm light on the carved details.

scenes.script: The attic faded away. Stone houses appeared. A narrow street with bumpy stones. Morning light came through. The air smelled like baking bread.
scenes.prompt: Magical transition - attic fading into Italian village. Cobblestone streets, stone buildings, warm morning light. Cozy European village atmosphere.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason followed the smell. He walked through the small streets. He found a little bakery. A wooden sign said 'Rossi' in old letters.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason walking through narrow Italian streets, following bread smell. Small bakery with old wooden 'Rossi' sign visible. Warm light from doorway.

scenes.script: Inside the bakery, he saw three people. An old grandfather was making dough. His son was at the oven. A teenage boy was wrapping bread.
scenes.prompt: Inside warm bakery. Three generations working: elderly Nonno with dough, Paolo at stone oven with paddle, young Marco wrapping loaves. Family teamwork.

scenes.script: The grandfather's name was Nonno. He had made bread for sixty years. His hands moved in the dough slowly. They knew just what to do.
scenes.prompt: Close view of Nonno's weathered hands kneading dough with practiced expertise. Calm, content expression. Flour dust in morning light. Master at work.

scenes.script: The father's name was Paolo. He used a long paddle. He put bread in the oven. He took bread out. The bread was golden and perfect.
scenes.prompt: Paolo using long wooden paddle at traditional brick oven. Golden perfect loaves visible. Warm orange glow from oven. Skilled craftsman.

scenes.script: The grandson's name was Marco. He was young like Mr. Mason. Marco wrapped the bread in paper. He talked to customers. He gave them change.
scenes.prompt: Marco at counter wrapping bread in paper, interacting with customers. Learning the business side. Friendly, engaged. Young apprentice.

scenes.script: Marco saw young Mr. Mason watching. 'You want to try?' Marco asked with a smile. 'Come, I will show you!'
scenes.prompt: Marco noticing young Mr. Mason at doorway, gesturing welcomingly to come in. Friendly invitation. Young Mr. Mason looking surprised but pleased.

scenes.script: The grandfather taught young Mr. Mason to knead. He put his hands in the dough. It was hard! The old man helped him. 'Not so hard. Be gentle.'
scenes.prompt: Nonno guiding young Mr. Mason's hands in dough. Patient teaching moment. Young Mr. Mason concentrating, learning. Flour on hands. Mentorship.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason tried to go fast. The grandfather stopped him. 'Bread cannot be rushed,' he said. 'Good things take time.'
scenes.prompt: Nonno gently stopping young Mr. Mason's hurried hands. Wise expression, teaching patience. Young Mr. Mason listening and slowing down.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason asked Paolo, 'Why do you all make bread?' Paolo smiled. 'My father taught me. I teach my son. We are keeping something alive.'
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason talking with Paolo near the oven. Paolo gesturing to his father and son, explaining family tradition. Pride visible.

scenes.script: Marco showed him the wooden stamp. They pressed it into every loaf. 'This stamp is older than my grandfather. Every loaf carries our name.'
scenes.prompt: Marco showing young Mr. Mason the wooden stamp being pressed into bread dough. Rossi pattern visible in the dough. Family legacy.

scenes.script: When young Mr. Mason left, the family gave him a gift. It was a bread stamp they had carved. 'Remember us. Making things with your hands matters.'
scenes.prompt: Three generations presenting young Mr. Mason with a carved wooden stamp gift. Heartfelt goodbye moment. Connection between strangers.

scenes.script: The bakery faded away. Flour dust became attic dust. They were back. Mr. Mason held the stamp. It was the same one from the story.
scenes.prompt: Magical transition - bakery fading, flour becoming dust motes. Attic returning. Old Mr. Mason holding the same bread stamp. Memory preserved.

scenes.script: 'Three generations,' said Mr. Mason. 'Same bakery. Same love.' He held the stamp close. The friends were quiet. They felt something warm.
scenes.prompt: Mr. Mason holding stamp close to heart, emotional moment. Friends sitting quietly, moved by the story. Warmth and connection.

scenes.script: The friends thought about their own families. 'My grandma paints,' said Riley. 'Maybe that is why I like art.' Benny added, 'My dad fixes things.'
scenes.prompt: Friends reflecting on their own families. Riley speaking about her grandmother, Benny talking about his dad. Personal connections forming.

scenes.script: Ellis had an idea. 'We should ask our families about their jobs!' he said. 'Like an interview. What do they do? How did they learn?'
scenes.prompt: Ellis excited with an idea, suggesting family interviews. Other friends looking interested and enthusiastic. Planning forming.

scenes.script: Layla connected it to their market. 'At our Community Market, people could teach things. Not just sell things. They could share what they know!'
scenes.prompt: Layla having breakthrough idea, gesturing excitedly. Other friends nodding, seeing the vision. Market becoming about more than selling.

scenes.script: Mr. Mason smiled proudly. 'Now you are thinking well,' he said. 'A market is not just about stuff. It is about knowledge. It is about people helping each other.'
scenes.prompt: Mr. Mason smiling proudly at the friends. Approving of their growth. Wisdom being passed to new generation. Full circle moment.

scenes.script: The friends felt excited. More stories waited in the trunk. Their Community Market was becoming something bigger. 'What else is in there?'
scenes.prompt: Four friends gathered around trunk with Mr. Mason, anticipating more stories. Excitement building. Market plans growing. Journey continuing.
